# Understanding The Problem Domain Is The Hardest Part Of Programming

the problem domain is hard because it is like a bluury picture you not given complete information about the problem domain, so you donâ€™t even have the information you need to understand it, so it is important to identify the problem domain and try to have complete informations to understand it, then the hardest part will be the easier part. but you will not be able to do this before understanding the questions and thinking about how to write the codes before starting writing the codes, one of the methodes you can use to make problem domain easier by cutting out cases and focus to a particular part of the problem.

# Object Literals

Objects group together a set of variables and functions to create a model of a something you would recognize from the real world.

- IN AN OBJECT: VARIABLES BECOME KNOWN AS PROPERTIES
  - The value of a property can be a string, number, Boolean, array, or even another object. The value of a method is always a function.
- IN AN OBJECT: FUNCTIONS BECOME KNOWN AS METHODS

![](data:image/png;base64,)

## creating an object : letiral notation

literal notation is the easiest way to creat obects.

## accessing an object

- the properties of an object using dot notation or square brackets
- the methods of an object using dot notation

![](data:image/png;base64,)

# Document Object Model

The Document Object Model (DOM) specifies how browsers should create a model of an HTML page and how JavaScript can access and update the contents of a web page while it is in the browser window.

![](data:image/png;base64,)

## THE DOM TREE IS A MODEL OF A WEB PAGE

the main types of nodes.

- THE DOCUMENT NODE
- ELEMENT NODES
- ATTRIBUTE NODES
- TEXT NODES

## Accessing and updating the DOM tree involves two steps:

- Locate the node that represents the element you want to work with.
- Use its text content, child elements, and attributes.

## METHODS THAT RETURN A SINGLE ELEMENT NODE:

- getElementByld('id')
- query Selector('css selector')

## METHODS THAT RETURN ONE OR MORE ELEMENTS (AS A NODELIST):

When a DOM method can return more than one element, it returns a Nodelist (even if it only finds one matching element).

- getEl ementsByClassName('class')
  - The get El ementsByCl ass Name() method allows you to select elements whose c 1 ass attribute contains a specific value.
- getEl ementsByTagName('tagName')
  - The get El ementsByTagName () method allows you to select elements using their tag name.
- querySelectorAll ('css selector')
  - querySe 1 ector() returns the first element node that matches the CSS-style selector. querySe 1ectorA11 () returns a Nodelist of all of the matches.

## SELECTING ELEMENTS USING ID ATTRIBUTES

- get El ementByi d () allows you to select a single element node by specifying the value of its id attribute.

## SELECTING AN ELEMENT FROM A NODELIST

There are two ways to select an element from a Nodelist:

- THE item() METHOD
- array syntax

## LOOPING THROUGH A NODELIST

If you want to apply the same code to numerous elements, looping through a Nodelist is a powerful technique, Each time the loop runs, the script checks that the counter is less than the total number of items in the Nodelist.

## TRAVERSING THE DOM

to select another element in relation to element node, using these five properties. This is known as traversing the DOM.

- parentNode
- previousSibling nextSibling
- firstChild lastChild
  - These properties also return inconsistent results if there is whitespace between elements

## ACCESSING & CHANGI NG A TEXT NODE

To work with text in an element, first the element node is accessed and then its text node. The text node has a property called node Value which returns the text in that text node. You can also use the node Va 1 ue property to update the content of a text node.

## adding or removing HTML content

- the innerHTML property
- DOM manipulation

## ADDING ELEMENTS USING DOM MANIPULATION

1. CREATE THE ELEMENT

- createEl ement ()

2. GIVE IT CONTENT

- createTextNode()

3. ADD IT TO THE DOM

- appendChild()

## REMOVING ELEMENTS VIA DOM MANIPULATION

1. STORE THE ELEMENT TO BE REMOVED IN A VARIABLE
1. STORE THE PARENT OF THAT ELEMENT IN A VARIABLE
1. REMOVE THE ELEMENT FROM ITS CONTA INING ELEMENT

## UPDATING HTML CONTENT

- document.write()
  - ADVANTAGES
    - It is a quick and easy way to show beginners how content can be added to a page.
  - DISADVANTAGES
    - It only works when the page initially loads.
    - It can cause problems with XHTML pages
    - This method is very rarely used by programmers
- element.innerHTML
  - ADVANTAGES
    - You can use it to add a lot of new markup using less code than DOM manipulation methods.
    - It can be faster than DOM manipulation
    - It is a simple way to remove all of the content from one element
  - DISADVANTAGES
    - It should not be used to add content that has come from a user
    - It can be difficult to isolate single elements that you want to update within a larger DOM fragment.
- DOM MANIPULATION
  - ADVANTAGES
    - It does not affect event handlers.
    - It easily allows a script to add elements
  - DISADVANTAGES
    - If you have to make a lot of changes to the content of a page, it is slower than i nnerHTML.
    - You need to write more code to achieve the same thing compared with i nnerHTML

## DEFENDING AGAINST CROSS-SITE SCRIPTING

![](data:image/png;base64,)

## XSS: VALIDATION & TEMPLATES

Make sure that your users can only input characters they need to use and limit where this content will be shown on the page.

- FILTER OR VALIDATE INPUT
- LIMIT WHERE USER CONTENT GOES

## XSS: ESCAPING & CONTROLLING MARKUP

Any content generated by users that contain characters that are used in code should be escaped on the server. You must control any markup added to the page.

- ESCAPING USER CONTENT
  - HTML
    - Escape these characters so that they are displayed as characters (not processed as code).
  - URLS
    - If you have links containing user input use the JavaScript encodeURIComponent () method to encode the user input. It encodes the following characters: , I ? : @ & = + $ #
- ADDING USER CONTENT
  - JAVASCRIPT
    - DO use: textContent or innerText
    - DO NOT use: innerHTML
  - JQUERY
    - DO use: . text ()
    - DO NOT use: . html()

## EXAM INING THE DOM IN CHROME

To get the developer tools in Chrome on a Mac, go to the View menu, select Developer and then Developer Tools. On a PC, go to Tools (or M ore Tools) and select Developer Tools. Or right-click on any element and select Inspect Element. Select Elements from the menu that runs across the top of this tool. The source of the page will be shown on the left and several other options to the right. The Properties panel (on the right) tells you the type of object the selected element is. (In some
versions of Chrome this is shown When you highlight different elements in the main left-hand window, you can see the values in the Properties panel on the right reflect that element.
